indicator_definition: Percentage of primary and secondary school children normally travelling to school in an active way (walking, cycling, and using a scooter, skateboard or inline/roller skates).
data_source: Hands Up Scotland Survey (HUSS), Sustrans (Official statistic)
inclusion_rationale: Children should have opportunities to be physically active. Physical activity has benefits for children’s growth, development, mental health and wellbeing, and can contribute to the prevention of many chronic conditions such as obesity and diabetes. Active travel, including to and from school, offers an opportunity to incorporate regular physical activity into a child’s daily routine. The Scottish Government has prioritised ‘increasing physical activity’ in the general population by making it a national indicator.
numerator: All primary and secondary school children (excluding SEN) who report they normally travel to school in an active way (walking, cycling, and using a scooter, skateboard or inline/roller skates).
denominator: All primary and secondary children (excluding SEN) participating in the survey. Response rate varies across local authorites, years and school type. Please see notes and caveats section.
available_geographies: Council area, Health board, HSCP, ADP, Scotland
notes_caveats:
Sustrans does not employ quota-based sampling or selective participation mechanisms. The ScotPHO indicator includes children attending state funded primary and secondary schools participating in HUSS, excluding Special Educational Needs (SEN) schools. 
 
 There are limitations to the comparability of data across years; although survey design and methodology have remained consistent, survey sample size has increased considerably. Response rates vary by year and geography.
 
 Data in the following Local Authorities and years is based on primary school responses only: 
 Falkirk (2008, 2009), Dundee City (2009), West Dunbartonshire (2009, 2010, 2011), Glasgow City (2012). 
 
 In these cases, data is not directly comparable to other local authorities and other years where both primary and secondary school data is aggregated. 
 
 There was a particularly low rate of response (less than 25%) from the following years and local authorities: 
 ∙ ≤ 5% - Secondary – 
 Argyll and Bute (2008, 2012), Clackmannanshire (2018), Dundee City (2010), Orkney (2011), Western Isles (2010, 2018)
 
 ∙ ≤ 25% - Secondary – 
 Argyll and Bute (2011, 2013), Clackmannanshire (2014), Dumfries & Galloway (2008), Dundee City (2013), East Dunbartonshire (2011), East Renfrewshire (2017), Edinburgh City (2009, 2016, 2017, 2018), Glasgow City (2008, 2010, 2011, 2013, 2014, 2017, 2018), North Lanarkshire (2008), Orkney (2010), South Ayrshire (2010, 2012), Stirling (2011), West Dunbartonshire (2012), Western Isles (2009, 2012, 2014) 
 
 ∙ ≤ 25% - Primary – 
 Edinburgh City (2009)
 
 Care should be taken when interpreting these results. For full details on response rates

indicator_name: Alcohol treatment waiting times - % where LDP Standard (90%) not met
indicator_definition: The LDP Standard is that 90% of people referred for help with problematic drug or alcohol use will wait no longer than three weeks for specialist treatment that supports their recovery.
data_source:
These data were extracted from the Drug and Alcohol Information System (DAISy) and its predecessor the Drug and Alcohol Treatment Waiting Times (DATWT) database. DAISy was available in all NHS Boards from April 2021 and replaces two previous systems: the DATWT database and the Scottish Drug Misuse Database (SDMD). DAISy and its predecessors hold data in relation to drug and alcohol treatments and waiting times from services throughout Scotland delivering tier 3 and 4 interventions (i.e. structured community and residential treatment). 
 
 Further information on DAISy can be found here: https://www.publichealthscotland.scot/our-areas-of-work/substance-use/data-and-intelligence/drug-and-alcohol-information-system-daisy/
numerator: Number of referrals waiting more than 3 weeks
available_geographies: Alcohol & drug partnership, Health board, Scotland
notes_caveats:
The implementation of DAISy introduced changes to how data are captured, and these should be considered when making comparisons over time. A 'co-dependency' substance type was introduced for cases where the referral relates to treatment for problematic use of both alcohol and drugs. Previously in DATWT, such cases would have been allocated to either ’alcohol’ or ‘drug’ depending on the substance considered the dominant issue. 
 These data relate to number of referrals rather than number of individuals. Where people are referred to more than one service, they have more than one referral.
 
 Data includes referrals to community-based services (referrals to prison-based services are excluded).
 
 ADPs have the responsibility of ensuring the submission of accurate and up-to-date information by treatment services. To this end, each quarter ADPs are asked to check and confirm the data for their area. If an ADP is unable to confirm the data for a service, then the service is excluded from the data (both for the period of non-submission and all other periods). Ten (of 204) services have been excluded from this release as they were unable to confirm their data. For more information on the services excluded, see Section 5 of the National drug and alcohol treatment waiting times report, 1 April 2022 to 30 June 2022, available here: https://publichealthscotland.scot/publications/show-all-releases?id=20553

indicator_definition: General acute inpatient and day case stays in young people aged 11-25 years with a diagnosis of alcohol misuse in any position, 3-year rolling average number and directly age-sex standardised rate per 100,000 population.
numerator: Total number of general acute inpatient and day case stays in young people aged 11-25 years with a diagnosis of alcohol misuse in any position
disclosure_control: Statistical disclosure control has been applied.
notes_caveats:
Hospital activity data are collected across the NHS in Scotland and are based on nationally available information routinely drawn from hospital administrative systems across the country. The principal data source for general acute inpatient & day case stays is the SMR01 dataset. The count and rates presented in this indicator do not include attendance resulting in A&E attendance only. Each individual patient may have more than one stay and hence the number of people discharged within a year will be less than the total number of stays. When figures are broken down by geographical area and age the numbers in some categories can be very small; this indicator therefore uses a combined and averaged three-year period to ensure reasonably robust estimates for small areas. 
 
 Up to six diagnoses are recorded per admission, and episodes with either a main or a supplementary diagnosis of alcohol misuse are included. 
 
 Note that some caution is necessary when using these data, as alcohol misuse may only be suspected and may not always be recorded by the hospital. The figures presented here are based on all alcohol-related diagnoses throughout the hospital stay and will reflect prevalence in the catchment area as well as local policy with regard to hospital admission and discharge. For this indicator the discharge date refers to the end of the patient’s continuous hospital stay, which can be made up of a number of records depending if the patient has been transferred from one hospital to another or from one specialty to another during the stay. 
 
 Rates have been standardised to the European Standard Population 2013.
related_publications: Public Health Scotland publish annual [Alcohol related hospital statistics](https://publichealthscotland.scot/publications/alcohol-related-hospital-statistics/). This release includes the [Alcohol Consumption and Harms Dashboard](https://scotland.shinyapps.io/phs-health-achd/) which provides more detailed breakdowns of alcohol-related admissions at national, local and board level.

indicator_name: Annual participation (in education, training or employment) measure for 16 – 19 year olds
indicator_definition: Number and percentage of 16-19 year olds participating in education, training or employment.
data_source: Skills Development Scotland Annual Participation Measure
inclusion_rationale:
Sustainable and gainful employment is known to be beneficial to health and quality of life. In 2012 the Scottish Government made an explicit commitment to offer a place in learning or training to every 16-19 year old in Scotland not currently in employment or education. This pledge, detailed in Opportunities for All (OfA), aims to ensure all young people are supported in their path to achieving sustainable employment by equipping them with the knowledge and skills they need to achieve that. 
 
 Since August 2017, the Annual Participation Measure has been the source of the National Performance Framework indicator, “increase the proportion of young people in learning, training or work”.
numerator: Total number of people aged 16-19 included in the participation measure cohort with a classification of participating.
denominator: Total number of people aged 16-19 included in the participation measure cohort.
notes_caveats:
The participation measure cohort is based entirely on records held on the Skills Development Scotland (SDS) customer support system (CSS). 
 The method of calculating the participation measure takes account of all statuses for individuals over the course of the year. The participation classification of each young person is calculated by combining the number of days spent in each status between 1st April and 31st March in the reporting period. The overall participation classification (participating, not participating and unconfirmed) is based on the classification which accounts for the greatest number of days. Only those with status data for the full reporting period i.e. 1st April - 31st March, are inlcuded in the measure.
 The young person is included in the cohort if they are aged 16-19 on or before the 31st March in the reporting period. Those who have subsequently moved out of Scotland or are deceased are excluded.

indicator_definition: Number of attempted murder and serious assault crimes recorded by the police and rate per 10,000 population.
numerator: Number of attempted murder and serious assault crimes recorded by the police.
available_geographies: HSC, Council area, Health board, ADP, Scotland
notes_caveats:
These data were extracted from the Police Scotland data repository, called the Source for Evidence Based Policing (SEBP). Prior to 2020/21, the data were collected from the Scottish Operational and Management Information System (ScOMIS). The Scottish Government found [strong alignment](https://www.gov.scot/binaries/content/documents/govscot/publications/statistics/2024/06/recorded-crime-scotland-2023-24/documents/recorded-crime-scotland-2023-24/recorded-crime-scotland-2023-24/govscot%3Adocument/recorded-crime-scotland-2023-24.pdf#page=64) between the administrative systems. 

[Serious assault](https://www.gov.scot/publications/recorded-crime-scotland-attempted-murder-serious-assault-2008-09-2017-18/pages/6/) refers to any attack where the victim needs hospital inpatient treatment or has any fractures/broken bones, internal injuries, severe concussion, lacerations that require stitches which may lead to impairment or disfigurement, or any other injury which may lead to impairment or disfigurement. [Attempted murder](https://www.gov.scot/publications/recorded-crime-scotland-attempted-murder-serious-assault-2008-09-2017-18/pages/6/) is defined as attempting to kill without necessary cause, or acting in a way so reckless as to show the perpetrator was utterly regardless of the consequences.

This indicator measures recorded crimes and offences combined in contrast to the Scottish Government which refers to these separately. Intermediate zones named "Hillhead" in Glasgow City council area and "Western Edge" in Dundee council area have been removed as the data could not be linked.

indicator_definition: Number of babies reported by parent as being exclusively breastfed at 6-8 week review; 3-year rolling average number and percentage of all babies with a valid feeding status recorded at 6-8 week review.
data_source: Child Health Systems Programme Pre-school (CHSP-PS), Public Health Scotland
inclusion_rationale: Every child has the right to be nurtured so that they thrive and develop into a healthy child, young person and adult. Being breastfed in infancy is highly beneficial for health in childhood and in later life. It is considered one of the most critical behaviours for health promotion and protection, and the World Health Organization recommends that babies are breastfed exclusively until six months of age.
numerator: Total number of babies reported as being exclusively breastfed at 6-8 week review
denominator: Total number of babies with a valid feeding status recorded at 6-8 week review
available_geographies: Intermediate zone, HSC locality, HSC partnership, Council area, Health board, Scotland
notes_caveats:
These statistics are derived from breastfeeding data recorded at the 6-8 week review, for NHS Boards in Scotland which participate in the Child Health Systems Programme Pre-School system (CHSP-PS). 
 
  Among participating NHS Boards, the majority of 6-8 week reviews are carried out before babies are 9 weeks old. The maximum age limit for the 6-8 week review is recommended as 12 weeks. Variation in the timing of the 6-8 week review may affect the reported rates as there is a known drop-off in breastfeeding rates with time.
 
  The number of NHS Boards using the CHSP Pre-School system and recording data has increased since 2003/04 from 10 to all 14 NHS Boards in Scotland. NHS Western Isles have recorded data from 2006/07, NHS Shetland from 2008/09, and NHS Grampian and NHS Orkney from 2010/11. Data for NHS Grampian and NHS Orkney for 2010/11 are partial. In addition it should be noted that NHS Highland did not fully implement the system until May 2007. Further information regarding data quality and completeness can be obtained from the Breastfeeding Statistics Scotland linked in related publications.

data_source: Scottish Bowel Screening Database (Public Health Scotland)
numerator: Number of people completing a screening test
available_geographies: Intermediate zone, HSC locality, HSC partnership, Council area, Health board, Scotland
notes_caveats:
The Scottish Bowel Screening Programme invites those aged 50 to 74 to be screened every two years. Participants are sent a test kit to their home and return a sample from a bowel motion to the Bowel Screening Laboratory. Those with a positive test result are referred to their health board of residence for follow-up, with the majority receiving a colonoscopy.
 
 The programme was paused in March 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, and resumed in October 2020. As a result, the screening population for 2020 will be smaller than previous years.
 
 The Scottish Bowel Screening Programme commenced a phased roll out in June 2007 and by December 2009 all NHS Boards in Scotland were participating in the Programme. All men and women registered with a Community Health Index (CHI) number and aged 50-74 years are invited to participate and be screened every two years.
 
 Eligible age range in the Scottish Bowel Screening Programme is 50 - 74 years, however the dataset shows persons aged 49 and persons aged 75 too, due to the fact that there are issues with odd timing of invitations and how it gets recorded in the system.
  
 2007 not included as it only started in June.

indicator_definition: Number of crimes classified as threatening and abusive behaviour recorded by the police (including threatening or abusive behaviour and breach of the peace) and rate per 10,000 population.
numerator: Number of threatening and abusive behaviour crimes recorded by the police.
available_geographies: HSC, Council area, Health board, ADP, Scotland
notes_caveats:
These data were extracted from the Police Scotland data repository, called the Source for Evidence Based Policing (SEBP). Prior to 2020/21, the data were collected from the Scottish Operational and Management Information System (ScOMIS). The Scottish Government found [strong alignment](https://www.gov.scot/binaries/content/documents/govscot/publications/statistics/2024/06/recorded-crime-scotland-2023-24/documents/recorded-crime-scotland-2023-24/recorded-crime-scotland-2023-24/govscot%3Adocument/recorded-crime-scotland-2023-24.pdf#page=64) between the administrative systems. 

These figures include the crimes of Threatening and Abusive Behaviour and Breach of the Peace. Breach of the Peace is differentiated from Threatenign and Abusive Behaviour in that it must "threaten serious disturbance to the community", whereas Threatening and Abusive Behaviour does not require a public element.

The [Domestic Abuse (Scotland) Act 2018](https://www.gov.scot/publications/recorded-crime-scotland-2023-24/pages/19/), which was enacted in 2019/20, specified that where offenses that historically constituted Breach of the Peace formed part of a domestic abuse incident, they should be recorded under the new offense of Domestic Abuse. Therefore, caution should be taken when comparing with years prior to the change. 

This indicator measures recorded crimes and offences combined in contrast to the Scottish Government publication which refers to these separately. Intermediate zones named "Hillhead" in Glasgow City council area and "Western Edge" in Dundee council area have been removed as the data could not be linked. 

This indicator was previously known as "Breach of the Peace" and has changed name to align with changes in crime groupings at the Scottish Government.

indicator_definition: Number and percentage of Primary 1 children receiving a letter 'C' (no obvious decay experience but should continue to see the family dentist on a regular basis) at basic inspection.
data_source: National Dental Inspection Programme Basic Inspection, Public Health Scotland
numerator: Number of Primary 1 children receiving a letter 'C' at basic inspection
denominator: Total number of Primary 1 children receving a basic inspection
available_geographies: Intermediate zone, HSC locality, HSC partnership, Council area, Health board, Scotland
confidence_interval_method: Wilson's Score method (using finite population correction factor)
notes_caveats:
The National Dental Inspection Programme (NDIP) is an annual programme aimed at informing parents/carers of the oral health status of their children. Appropriately anonymised and aggregated data from the programme is used to advise the Scottish Government, NHS Boards and other organisations of oral disease prevalence at national and local levels. This ensures that reliable oral health information is available for planning initiatives directed towards health improvements. 
 
 Numbers are based on the postcode of the child’s home address and not the postcode of the school where the child was inspected. There may be some slight differences between profiles and other published data due to the different methods used when matching pupils to their respective geographies. This issue only has a minor effect on Lanarkshire and Greater Glasgow and Clyde NHS Board figures and does not impact on the overall Scotland figures.
 
 Please not that due to the pandemic, there was no NDIP conducted for the school year 2020/21. For 2021/22, there was no inspections carried out in NHS Western Isles, and a very small number of inspections carried out in NHS Highland.
supporting_information: The Public health scotland website contains an [overview of dental health](https://publichealthscotland.scot/healthcare-system/primary-care/dental-care/overview/). Further information about the national dental inspection programme can also be found on the [NDIP website](https://ndip.scottishdental.org/).

indicator_name: Children registered for free school meals
indicator_definition: Number and percentage of children, in Primary 4 and above, registered for free school meals.
numerator: Number of children in Primary 4 and above registered for free school meals
denominator: Total number of pupils in Primary 4 and above on the school roll
age_group: All school-aged children primary 4 and above
notes_caveats:
In this measure, a child is considered to be in a low-income family if they are living in a family that is either:-
  a) in receipt of out-of-work benefits (Income Support (IS), Income-Based Jobseekers Allowance (JSA), Employment and Support Allowance (ESA) and Pension Credit (PC)) 
  or
  b) has a reported income less than 60 per cent of national median income (identified through receipt of Child Tax Credits).
  
  The total number of children in any given area is produced using Child Benefit data held by HMRC, typically covering around 96 per cent of all children in the UK. From January 2013, if a claimant of Child Benefit or their partner has an individual income of more than £50,000 per year, they are liable to repay some or all of their Child Benefit due to the introduction of the High Income Child Benefit charge. Claimants affected by the High Income Child Benefit charge have the option to opt-out of receiving Child Benefit. Therefore, the total number of children used in this publication includes numbers for claimants that have opted out of receiving Child Benefit, and the children that they are responsible for. This means that the measure may not be as complete as it has been previously due to families with higher incomes no longer claiming Child benefit.
  
  All of the estimates are independently rounded to the nearest 5, therefore aggregating the individual estimates may not sum to the given totals for an area. The estimates are based on the finalised awards tax credits data, and as such are derived from a full set of administrative records rather than a sample. From this data the “sub-period” of the award that spanned the 31st August is selected.
  
  From 2013 the data has been produced using 2011 data zone geographies and is not directly comparable with earlier data. The trend in the profile is therefore only currently available from 2013 onwards.

indicator_definition: Deaths from suicide in young people aged 11-25 years; 5-year rolling average number and crude rate per 100,000 people aged 11-25 years.

disclosure_control: Values less than 5 are suppressed in cases where NRS do not publish these counts

notes_caveats:
With the exception of the deprivation (SIMD) analysis, time series have been refreshed using 2022 census rebased populations from 2011 to 2021.  Deprivation (SIMD) based analysis is only available up to 2023 and should be considered provisional, this time series will be refreshed once rebased and updated SAPE 2024 populations released by NRS (expected Winter 2025).

A suicide is defined as a death resulting from intentional self-harm or undetermined intent. The data comprises suicides occurring in Scotland registered by the National Records of Scotland (NRS). This includes a small proportion of deaths for persons who were not resident in Scotland, who are assigned to their place of death instead, and excludes deaths of residents of Scotland occurring outwith Scotland. Deaths data are analysed by date of registration of death rather than date of death. They will be updated when the 2023 data become available. Published estimates are 5-year rolling averages to allow sufficient counts to enable calculation and comparisons of rates split by gender and SIMD quintile.

In 2011, NRS changed its coding practice with some deaths previously coded under 'mental and behavioural disorders' now being classed as 'self-poisoning of undetermined intent' and consequently as undetermined intent suicides. This indicator presents data based on the new coding rule only; this combined with the need to aggregate over years results in the lack of trend data being available. 
 
 The indicator is presented as a crude rate per 100,000 population. Standardisation has not been applied due to the small numbers in some geographical areas. Standardisation of rates calculated from small numbers can result in large fluctuations which may in fact be due to just a few deaths.

indicator_name: Drug and alcohol co-dependency treatment waiting times - % where LDP Standard (90%) not met
indicator_definition: The LDP Standard is that 90% of people referred for help with problematic drug or alcohol use will wait no longer than three weeks for specialist treatment that supports their recovery.
data_source: These data were extracted from the Drug and Alcohol Information System (DAISy) and its predecessor the Drug and Alcohol Treatment Waiting Times (DATWT) database. DAISy was available in all NHS Boards from April 2021 and replaces two previous systems: the DATWT database and the Scottish Drug Misuse Database (SDMD). DAISy and its predecessors hold data in relation to drug and alcohol treatments and waiting times from services throughout Scotland delivering tier 3 and 4 interventions (i.e. structured community and residential treatment).
numerator: Number of referrals waiting more than 3 weeks
available_geographies: Alcohol & drug partnership, Health board, Scotland
notes_caveats:
The implementation of DAISy introduced changes to how data are captured, and these should be considered when making comparisons over time. A 'co-dependency' substance type was introduced for cases where the referral relates to treatment for problematic use of both alcohol and drugs. Previously in DATWT, such cases would have been allocated to either ’alcohol’ or ‘drug’ depending on the substance considered the dominant issue. 
 These data relate to number of referrals rather than number of individuals. Where people are referred to more than one service, they have more than one referral.
 Data includes referrals to community-based services (referrals to prison-based services are excluded).
 ADPs have the responsibility of ensuring the submission of accurate and up-to-date information by treatment services. To this end, each quarter ADPs are asked to check and confirm the data for their area. If an ADP is unable to confirm the data for a service, then the service is excluded from the data (both for the period of non-submission and all other periods). Ten (of 204) services have been excluded from this release as they were unable to confirm their data. For more information on the services excluded, see Section 5 of the National drug and alcohol treatment waiting times report, 1 April 2022 to 30 June 2022, available here: https://publichealthscotland.scot/publications/show-all-releases?id=20553

indicator_definition: Estimated female life expectancy at birth in years, multi-year average (over 3 years for NHS Boards and Local Authorities, 5 years for Intermediate zones and for life expectancy by deprivation quintile)
data_source: Public Health Scotland/National Records of Scotland (NRS)
numerator: Life expectancy at birth for females
aggregation: Aggregation depends on geography size.IZ & by SIMD Quintile: 5-year aggregate, LA,HB, Scotland: 3 year aggregate
available_geographies: Intermediate zone, Council area, Health board, Scotland, HSCP Partnership and HSCP Locality
notes_caveats:
Life Expectancy (LE) at birth for an area is the number of years that a newborn baby would live if they experienced the age-specific mortality rates for that area, for the time period used, throughout their life. It is a theoretical measure that reflects recent mortality rates throughout life, rather than a true prediction of the life expectancy of the local population. The calculations use abridged life tables, with LE calculations based on Chiang (II) methodology. They use NRS mid-year population estimates (or SAPE small area population estimates for IZ and HSCP localities) and death registrations (by year of registration).
 
 Chiang CL, The life table and its construction, in Chiang CL, Introduction to stochastic processes in Biostatistics. New York, John Wiley 1968
 
For the NHS Board and local authority, LE is calculated over three-year time periods, in line with the NRS publication. For the intermediate zones due to the severe instability of the small numbers, LE is calculated over five-year periods. Please note that the data points indicated on a time trend charts represent mid-point within the three or five-year period depending on selected geography level. That is, for the NHS board and local authority showed year 2011 represents the mid-point for 2010-2012 period, while for intermediate zone it represents 2009-2013 period. 
 
To avoid the least robust situations for the intermediate zones, LE for an area is not calculated where: the five-year total population for that sex was less than 5,000 people; and/or there were fewer than 40 deaths for that sex over the 5-year period.
For a small number of intermediate zones LE could not be calculated because an age group had a zero population estimate or no deaths had occurred in the oldest (85+ years) age group. This means some extreme LE estimates are omitted from the full range for intermediate geographies within Scotland.  Over the time period 2009-13, amongst the remaining data for intermediate geographies, LE at birth ranged from 58.4 to 92.0 years for males, and from 70.3 to 94.4 years for females.
 
Please note that some of these data have large 95% confidence intervals (up to 14 or 12 years). The implications of this are best explained using an example. The lowest remaining male LE at birth (58.4 years) has a confidence interval of 8.0 years, from 54.4 to 62.4 years. This means that there is a 1 in 20 chance that the true LE at birth lies either below 54.4 years or above 62.4 years (although the most likely true value remains at 58.4 years). The wide range of possible values indicates that further caution is required in drawing conclusions about the apparent ranking of small areas.
source_details: NRS provide source data for Scotland, NHS Board and LA. ScotPHO produce IZ level data See GitHub project folder for calculation methodology. SIMD quintile estimates provided by NRS on request

indicator_name: Looked after school leavers in positive destinations
indicator_definition: Number and percentage of looked after school leavers, aged 16-19 years, in positive destinations at 9 month follow up.
inclusion_rationale: Local authorities have a responsibility to provide support to a group of vulnerable young people, known as ‘looked after children’. A young person may become looked after for a number of reasons, including neglect, abuse, complex disabilities which require specialist care, or involvement in the youth justice system. On average, children who have been looked after at some point in their childhood have worse educational outcomes than their peers which can in turn lead to poorer outcomes in later life.

denominator: Total number of looked after school leavers aged 16-19 years
notes_caveats: Education outcomes for looked after children are produced annually by the Scottish Government. The Scottish Candidate Number is linked to social work records, the linkage allows detailed analysis of education outcomes for the looked after child population. Skills Development Scotland (on behalf of the Scottish Government) collect data on school leaver destinations in the September after leaving school and again in the following March (at 9 months post leaving). Positive destinations include: Higher Education, Further Education, employment, training, voluntary work or activity agreements. Owing to data suppression by the provider some Health Board totals may not include data that have been suppressed at local authority level. 2018 data for Glasgow City Council was not provided by the data provider and could not be included in the profile; the Scottish total is therefore lower than in previous years. The percentage for Scotland in 2017/18 has been adjusted by removing the Glasgow City population of looked after school leavers from the denominator.

indicator_definition: Mean score for S4 pupils on the Warwick-Edinburgh Mental Wellbeing Scale (WEMWBS)
data_source: Scottish Schools Adolescent Lifestyle and Substance Use Survey (SALSUS)
numerator: Sum of all the valid S4 responses to this survey question
denominator: Total S4 pupils who provided a valid answer to this survey question
notes_caveats:
The SALSUS time trend data set, available form the UK Data Service, has been used to produce this indicator (link below).
  
  The Warwick-Edinburgh Mental Wellbeing Scale (WEMWBS), developed by researchers at the Universities of Warwick and Edinburgh, is a tool for measuring mental wellbeing at a population level. It comprises 14 positively worded statements that relate to an individual’s state of mental wellbeing. Added to the SALSUS in 2010, pupils were asked to indicate how often they have had such thoughts and feelings over the last two weeks. Each statement has a five item scale ranging from '1 - None of the time' to '5 - All of the time'. The lowest possible score is therefore 14 and the highest is 70.
  
  Numerators are not presented in the spine chart; this is due to the relatively small number of people, when compared to the population, being included in the survey.
  Weighting has been used to correct for any effects of non-response to ensure that the results are representative on various characteristics of the target population.
  The sample design of SALSUS is complex, involving stratification by local authority and school type (state or independent) as well as clustering within schools. Clustering reduces the precision of estimates compared with a simple random sample, whereas stratification can increase precision. Weighting can also reduce the precision of estimates. These factors can impact on the reliability of the confidence intervals presented here; this should be taken into consideration when interpreting this indicator. For more information please see the SALSUS technical document (link below).
related_publications: [Scottish Schools Adolescent Lifestyle and Substance Use Survey Trend Data, 1990-2013](https://discover.ukdataservice.ac.uk/catalogue/?sn=7849&type=Data%20catalogue)

indicator_name: Mean total difficulties score for S4 pupils
indicator_definition: Mean total difficulties score for S4 pupils from the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ)
data_source: Scottish Schools Adolescent Lifestyle and Substance Use Survey (SALSUS)
numerator: Sum of all the valid S4 responses to this survey question
denominator: Total S4 pupils who provided a valid answer to this survey question
notes_caveats:
The SALSUS time trend data set, available from the UK Data Service, has been used to produce this indicator (link below).
  
  The Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ) is brief behavioural screening questionnaire widely used by researchers, clinicians and education professionals. The questionnaire comprises 25 items that are grouped into 5 scales, with each scale including 5 questions. The scales
  are: emotional symptoms, conduct problems, hyperactivity/inattention, peer relationship problems and pro-social behaviour. The total difficulties score is calculated from the first 4 scales; it does not include data from the pro-social scale. The SDQ has been included in SALSUS since 2006.

Weighting has been used to correct for any effects of non-response to ensure that the results are representative on various characteristics of the target population.
  The sample design of SALSUS is complex, involving stratification by local authority and school type (state or independent) as well as clustering within schools. Clustering reduces the precision of estimates compared with a simple random sample, whereas stratification can increase precision. Weighting can also reduce the precision of estimates. These factors can impact on the reliability of the confidence intervals presented here; this should be taken into consideration when interpreting this indicator. For more information please see the SALSUS technical document (link below).

indicator_name: Multiple emergency hospital admissions, aged >65 years
indicator_definition: Patients aged 65+ years with 2 or more emergency hospital admissions, discharged from hospital: 3 year rolling average number and directly age-sex standardised rate per 100,000 population.
diagnostic_code_position: Admission codes 20 to 22, 30 to 40 (emergency and urgent admissions)
numerator: Number of patients over 65 admitted multiple times to hospital
available_geographies: Intermediate zone, HSC locality, HSC partnership, Council area, Health board, Scotland
notes_caveats:
2022 populations have been temporarily used for small areas in 2023, due to data availability. This affects data for HSCP localities, Intermediate Zones, and inequalities metrics (SII and RII). These data should be considered provisional. They will be updated when the 2023 data become available.

If one patient has 2 emergency admissions to hospital in a year and another patient has 10 emergency admissions to hospital in the same year, then they would simply count as 2 patients with multiple emergency admissions.
 
 Since information is shown for different geographical levels of analysis (e.g. NHS Board, LA and IZ) it is likely that the data may show some inconsistencies, e.g. will be counted as multiple admissions.
related_publications: [Acute hospital activity and NHS beds information publication](https://publichealthscotland.scot/publications/acute-hospital-activity-and-nhs-beds-information-annual/)
source_details: Public Health Scotland (SMR1/01, Linked Database) - extract data ourselves

indicator_name: People aged 65+ with high levels of care needs who are cared for at home
indicator_definition:
Number and percentage of people aged 65 and over who are receiving 10 and more hours of home care (purchased or provided by a local authority) out of all people with high levels of care needs within this age group. 
  
  People 65+ with high levels of care needs are defined as those who are: 
  - Receiving 10+ hours of home care (purchased or provided by a LA)
  - Resident in a Care Home
  - Resident long-term in NHS hospital.
numerator: Number of people receiving 10+ hours of home care
denominator:
Number of people aged 65+ receiving 10+ hours of home care
  + Number of people resident in Care Homes for older people
  + Number of long-stay residents aged 65+ in hospital
notes_caveats: NA
interpretation: Indicator is assigned to 'worse' if percentage is below the Scottish average.
source_details: Data comes from PHS balance of care publication tables. There is an R script to format the data.

indicator_name: People perceiving rowdy behaviour as common in their neighbourhood
indicator_definition: Percentage of people perceiving rowdy behaviour to be very/fairly common in their neighbourhood.
numerator: Number of respondents saying rowdy behaviour is very/fairly common in their neighbourhood
available_geographies: Alcohol & drug partnership, Health board, Scotland
notes_caveats: There was a change mode for the 2020 survey. Because of this, the results of the SHS 2020 telephone survey are not directly comparable to SHS results for previous years. Everything else being equal, we would expect some genuine changes in people’s views and experiences, due to the pandemic. However, it is not possible to determine whether differences between the 2020 results and previous years represent genuine changes in views and experiences, or are due to changes in how the survey was carried out. Response rates for the telephone survey were lower than usual, and there was a change in the profile of respondents (e.g. home owners and people with degree level qualifications were over-represented). There are also potential mode effects (respondents answering differently over the telephone than they would face-to-face) and seasonal effects (the telephone survey took place during October 2020 and January to March 2021, whereas SHS face-to-face surveys normally run throughout the year). The SHS 2020 methodology report provides more detail on the change in approach, and how it may have impacted the results https://www.gov.scot/publications/scottish-household-survey-2020-methodology-impact-change-mode/

indicator_name: Proportion of S4 pupils in good or excellent general health
indicator_definition: Proportion of S4 pupils who report they are in good or excellent general health
data_source: Scottish Schools Adolescent Lifestyle and Substance Use Survey (SALSUS)
numerator: Total number of S4 pupils reporting that they are in good or excellent general health
denominator: All S4 pupils participating the survey
notes_caveats:
The SALSUS time trend data set, available form the UK Data Service, has been used to produce this indicator (link below).
  Numerators are not presented in the tool; this is due to the relatively small number of people, when compared to the population, being included in the survey.
  Weighting has been used to correct for any effects of non-response to ensure that the results are representative on various characteristics of the target population.
  The sample design of SALSUS is complex, involving stratification by local authority and school type (state or independent) as well as clustering within schools. Clustering reduces the precision of estimates compared with a simple random sample, whereas stratification can increase precision. Weighting can also reduce the precision of estimates. These factors can impact on the reliability of the confidence intervals presented here; this should be taken into consideration when interpreting this indicator. For more information please see the SALSUS technical document (link below).
related_publications: [Scottish Schools Adolescent Lifestyle and Substance Use Survey Trend Data, 1990-2013](https://discover.ukdataservice.ac.uk/catalogue/?sn=7849&type=Data%20catalogue)

indicator_definition: Number and percentage of school leavers, aged 16-19 years, in positive destinations at 9 month follow up.
inclusion_rationale: Every child and young person has a right to the opportunities and support to maximise their potential. Those who leave school without qualifications are more likely to be unemployed, earn less and be in low-status jobs in the future. Further, those from the poorest backgrounds are more likely to leave school without qualifications, and the attainment gap between the richest and poorest is wider in Scotland than in many similar countries. The Scottish Government has prioritised equity in educational outcomes, with a particular focus on closing the poverty-related attainment gap.
numerator: Number of school leavers aged 16-19 years in positive destinations at 9 month follow up
denominator: Total number of school leavers aged 16-19 years
notes_caveats: Skills Development Scotland (on behalf of the Scottish Government) collect data on school leaver destinations in the September after leaving school and again in the following March (at 9 months post leaving). Positive destinations include: Higher Education, Further Education, employment, training, voluntary work or activity agreements. SIMD is based on pupil's home address.
related_publications: [Summary Statistics for Attainment and Initial Leaver Destinations, No. 7: 2025 edition](https://www.gov.scot/publications/summary-statistics-for-attainment-and-initial-leaver-destinations-no-7-2025-edition/)

indicator_definition: Emergency hospital admissions for unintentional injury in children under 5; 3-year rolling average number and directly age-sex standardised rate per 100,000 population.
inclusion_rationale: Every child and young person has the right to be and feel safe and protected from harm. Children are particularly vulnerable; unintentional injury is a leading cause of emergency hospital admission and death in children. The term ‘accident’ implies that an event is inevitable and unavoidable, so the term ‘unintentional injury’ is used to reflect the fact that many such events could be prevented.
diagnostic_code_position: The ICD-10 codes for unintentional injuries are V01-X59, Y85-Y86. Diagnosis in any position.

available_geographies: HSC Partnership, Council area, Health board
notes_caveats:
Based on date of admission. Many unintentional injuries will not result in hospital admission but are treated by the individual, GP, Accident and Emergency departments or by a child's parent or carer. This information is therefore not captured within this indicator.
  
  Hospital inpatient activity data is collected across NHS Scotland and is based on nationally available information routinely drawn from hospital administrative systems across the country. The principal data source is the SMR01 (acute inpatients and day cases) return. The count and rates presented in this indicator do not include attendance resulting in A&E attendance only. Up to six diagnoses are recorded per admission, and episodes with either a main or a supplementary diagnosis of unintentional injury are included. The ICD-10 codes for unintentional injuries are V01-X59, Y85-Y86.
  
  Rates have been standardised to the European Standard Population 2013.
 
  Based on date of admission. Maternity Publication figures are based on date of discharge.

indicator_name: People in households in persistent poverty
domain: Care & wellbeing - Ensure a healthy standard of living for all
indicator_definition: Percentage of people living in relative poverty (equivalised income of less than 60% of the UK median income in the same year, after housing costs) for three out of the last four years. Persistent poverty identifies people who have been living in poverty for a significant period of time, which is more damaging than brief periods spent with a low income. The impacts can affect an individual throughout their lifetime. The measure includes income from all sources (including earnings, benefits, tax credits, pensions, and investments) after deductions for income tax, national insurance contributions, council tax, pension contributions, maintenance payments, and rent and/or mortgage payments. Equivalisation adjusts each household's income to reflect the composition of each household, so that it is comparable with others. Communal establishments such as hostels, prisons or hospitals are excluded. The median is the middle value when the household income of all individuals in the UK are ranked in order. Sixty percent of the median is an internationally recognised poverty threshold.
numerator: Number of people living in households in relative poverty after housing costs for three out of the last four years.
denominator: Total population living in private households.
aggregation: 4-year aggregate of survey years (e.g. 2010-2014 is based on poverty status in 2010-2011, 2011-2012, 2012-2013, and 2013-2014)

domain: Care & wellbeing - Give every child the best start in life
indicator_definition: Percentage of children aged 4 to 12 years who have an "abnormal" or "borderline" total difficulties score on the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ) section of the Scottish Health Survey (SHeS). The child's guardian is asked to assess how true 25 statements about their child are (see page 228 of the [survey questionnaire](https://doc.ukdataservice.ac.uk/doc/9390/mrdoc/pdf/9390_shes_2022_questionnaire_documentation.pdf)). notes_caveats:
The Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ) measures wellbeing in Children aged 4 to 12 across five dimensions in order to score them for each dimension individually and to give each child a “total difficulties score”. The four dimensions included in the total difficulties score are Emotional Symptoms; Conduct Disorder; Hyperactivity; and Peer Problems. The “total difficulties score” a child receives can range from 0 to 40, with a higher score indicating more difficulties. Traditionally a three-band categorisation has been used whereby if an individual has a score between 0-13, they are deemed “normal”; 14-16 they are “borderline”; and 17-40, they are “abnormal”.
Data for 2017-2021 excludes 2020. For the mental health profile this represents a change of source for this indicator, compared with the original indicator set, due to the decision not to use the Health and Wellbeing Census.

indicator_definition: Rate of death by intentional self-harm and by undetermined intent ('probable suicides'), per 100,000 adults. Deaths by intentional self-harm and by undetermined intent are termed 'probable suicides'. International Classification of Disease (ICD-10) codes for intentional self-harm are X60-X84 and Y87.0, and for events of undetermined intent are Y10-Y34 and Y87.2. Rates are age-standardised using the European Standard Population (2013). Five-year rolling average. Deaths of individuals not resident in Scotland are included, to mirror NRS official statistics. Non-Scottish residents account for approximately 2% of all probable suicides.
numerator: Total number of adult deaths (16+ years) from probable suicide.
disclosure_control: Values less than 5 are suppressed in cases where NRS do not publish these counts
available_geographies: Scotland, CA, HB, HSCP, PD, ADP
notes_caveats:
With the exception of the deprivation (SIMD) analysis, time series have been refreshed using 2022 census rebased populations from 2011 to 2021.  Deprivation (SIMD) based analysis is only available up to 2023 and should be considered provisional, this time series will be refreshed once rebased and updated SAPE 2024 populations released by NRS (expected Winter 2025).

A suicide is defined as a death resulting from intentional self-harm or undetermined intent. The data comprises suicides occurring in Scotland registered by the National Records of Scotland (NRS). This includes a small proportion of deaths for persons who were not resident in Scotland, who are assigned to their place of death instead, and excludes deaths of residents of Scotland occurring outwith Scotland. Deaths data are analysed by date of registration of death rather than date of death. Published estimates are 5-year rolling averages to allow sufficient counts to enable calculation and comparisons of rates split by gender and SIMD quintile. 

In 2011, NRS changed its coding practice with some deaths previously coded under 'mental and behavioural disorders' now being classed as 'self-poisoning of undetermined intent' and consequently as undetermined intent suicides. This indicator presents data based on the new coding rule only; this combined with the need to aggregate over years results in the lack of trend data being available.

indicator_definition: Percentage of adults (16+ years) who met the daily fruit and vegetable consumption recommendation - five or more portions - in the previous day (survey variables porftvg3Intake and porftvg3). This is due to the inclusion of fruit and vegetables from composite dishes which has led to a decrease in the proportion consuming no fruit or vegetables. Data from earlier years were taken from the fruit and vegetable module. Fruit and vegetable consumption data for NHS health boards and council area areas for 2017-2021 combined are not available, as due to the different method of data collection, it was not possible to combine data for these years. Respondents to the INTAKE24 food diary were included if they had provided data for two days. indicator_definition: Percentage of adults (16+ years) with a possible common mental health problem. A score of four or more on the General Health Questionnaire-12 (GHQ-12) indicates a possible mental health problem over the past few weeks. GHQ-12 is a standardised scale which measures mental distress and mental ill-health. There are 12 questions which cover concentration abilities, sleeping patterns, self-esteem, stress, despair, depression, and confidence in the past few weeks (see pages 222-223 of the [survey questionnaire](https://doc.ukdataservice.ac.uk/doc/9390/mrdoc/pdf/9390_shes_2022_questionnaire_documentation.pdf)). For each of the 12 questions one point is given if the participant responded 'more than usual' or 'much more than usual'. Scores are then totalled to create an overall score of zero to twelve. A score of four or more (described as a high GHQ-12 score) is indicative of a potential psychiatric disorder. Conversely a score of zero is indicative of psychological wellbeing. As GHQ-12 measures only recent changes to someone's typical functioning it cannot be used to detect chronic conditions. The variable used was GHQg2. The SIMD figures were age-standardised to the population of Scotland to aid comparison between the quintiles.
numerator: Number of respondents scoring four or more on the General Health Questionnaire (GHQ-12)
denominator: Total number of respondents completing the questionnaire.
disclosure_control: Statistical disclosure control has been applied.
aggregation: Scotland Level - annual figures. Sub-national figures 4-year aggregate
notes_caveats: Results are not presented where the unweighted bases are below 30 participants. Due to sample size limitations sub-national breakdowns require 4 year aggregates rather than the single survey year that can be used at a Scotland level.
source_details: Published data downloaded from statistics.gov.scot; Additional splits (sex x SIMD) added from UK Data Service microdata.

If however the interviewer is pushed they are instructed to define 'Neighbourhood' as "the street you live in and the streets nearby" for 'urban' and "the local area" for 'rural'. Possible responses were 'very poor', 'fairly poor', 'fairly good', or 'very good'.

indicator_name: Households falling behind with debt or bill payments

The data are from the 'Wealth in Scotland' report (data.gov.scot/wealth). The estimates are based on Scotland data from the Office for National Statistics' Wealth and Assets Survey. The survey is not representative of the whole of the Scottish population because it does not cover regions north of the Caledonian Canal and the Scottish Islands. Breakdowns by sex refer to the sex of the household head (the person with the highest income, or, for equal incomes, the older person).
numerator: Number of households with unmanageable debt.
notes_caveats: The survey does not cover the regions north of the Caledonian Canal and the Scottish islands. It is therefore not representative of the whole of the Scottish population, and especially leaves out some of the most remote areas in Scotland.

indicator_definition: Percentage of households estimated to be living in fuel poverty as defined in the Fuel Poverty (Targets, Definition and Strategy) (Scotland) Act
numerator: NA
notes_caveats:
A household is considered to be in fuel poverty if, in order to maintain a satisfactory heating regime:

the total fuel costs necessary for the home are more than 10% of the household’s adjusted net income (after housing costs), and
if after deducting fuel costs, benefits received for a care need or disability and childcare costs, the household’s remaining adjusted net income is insufficient to maintain an acceptable standard of living. The remaining adjusted net income must be at least 90% of the UK Minimum Income Standard to be considered an acceptable standard of living, with an additional amount added for households in remote rural, remote small town and island areas.

indicator_definition: Number & Percent of dependent children (under 16 years) living in relative low income families. Relative low-income is defined as a family in low income Before Housing Costs (BHC) in the reference year. A family must have claimed Child Benefit and at least one other household benefit (Universal Credit, tax credits, or Housing Benefit) at any point in the year to be classed as low income in these statistics. Gross income measure is Before Housing Costs (BHC) and includes contributions from earnings, state support and pensions.
inclusion_rationale: Although there are several indicators related to low income/child poverty this indicator is one of the few child poverty indicators which provide granular (ie data available down to intermediate zone level) estimates of the number of children living in low income families

indicator_name: Children subject to child protection inter-agency referral discussions
indicator_definition: Number of children aged 17 years or under per 1,000 subject to interagency referral discussions. An IRD is a formal process used to address concerns about a child's safety and well-being. It involves sharing information and making decisions between key agencies like social work, police, and health services. The IRD is initiated when one of these agencies receives information suggesting a child may be experiencing or at risk of significant harm.  Therefore, an IRD is the first stage in formal child protection proceedings where young people may be at risk of harm or abuse.
numerator: Number of inter-agency referral discussions (IRDs)
denominator: Total number of children aged under 18 years
available_geographies: Council area, Health board, HSC partnership, Alcohol & drug partnership, Scotland
notes_caveats: A child may be subject to more than one IRD in one year. Data for Aberdeenshire not available in 2023/24, which will affect any totals that include this area.
interpretation: Values for this indicator are not categorised as ‘better’ or ‘worse’ than the Scottish average within the tool.
